description:
Daphnia pulex is a species of freshwater zooplankton belonging to the order Cladocera. It is a small, transparent crustacean, typically ranging from 0.2 to 3 millimeters in length. Daphnia pulex is a keystone species in many aquatic ecosystems, playing a crucial role in the food chain as a primary consumer of algae and microorganisms.

This species has a unique life cycle that involves both sexual and asexual reproduction. During favorable environmental conditions, Daphnia pulex reproduces parthenogenetically, producing genetically identical offspring. However, when environmental conditions become less favorable, such as during periods of resource scarcity or increased predation, Daphnia pulex can switch to sexual reproduction, producing resting eggs that can survive unfavorable conditions.

Daphnia pulex is an important model organism in various fields of study, including ecology, ecotoxicology, and developmental biology, due to its small size, rapid life cycle, and sensitivity to environmental changes. Its ability to respond to environmental cues and its wide distribution make it a valuable indicator species for monitoring the health of aquatic ecosystems.
